title: AST to Platelet Ratio Index (APRI)
description: Determines the likelihood of liver fibrosis and cirrhosis in patients with hepatitis C using AST levels and platelet count

parameters.name: ast_upper_limit_normal
parameters.description: Upper limit of normal for AST (typically 40 IU/L for most laboratories)

result.name: apri_score
result.description: APRI score calculated as [(AST/upper limit normal) × 100] / platelet count

ranges.interpretation: APRI score ≤0.5 suggests minimal or no liver fibrosis. High negative predictive value for ruling out significant fibrosis and cirrhosis.
APRI score 0.5-0.7 suggests possible mild fibrosis. Additional testing may be needed for definitive assessment.
APRI score 0.7-1.0 suggests significant hepatic fibrosis with 77% sensitivity and 72% specificity. Consider further evaluation.
APRI score 1.0-1.5 suggests cirrhosis with 76% sensitivity and 72% specificity. Further evaluation recommended.
APRI score 1.5-2.0 indicates high probability of cirrhosis. High positive predictive value for ruling in cirrhosis.
APRI score ≥2.0 indicates very high probability of cirrhosis with 91% specificity but 46% sensitivity. Strong positive predictor of cirrhosis.

references: Lin ZH, Xin YN, Dong QJ, et al. Performance of the aspartate aminotransferase-to-platelet ratio index for the staging of hepatitis C-related fibrosis: an updated meta-analysis. Hepatology. 2011;53(3):726-36.
Chou R, Wasson N. Blood tests to diagnose fibrosis or cirrhosis in patients with chronic hepatitis C virus infection: a systematic review. Ann Intern Med. 2013;158(11):807-20.
Wai CT, Greenson JK, Fontana RJ, et al. A simple noninvasive index can predict both significant fibrosis and cirrhosis in patients with chronic hepatitis C. Hepatology. 2003;38(2):518-26.
formula: APRI = [(AST ÷ AST Upper Limit Normal) × 100] ÷ Platelet Count
notes: APRI is most validated for hepatitis C patients but has been used in other liver diseases
Most laboratories use 40 IU/L as the upper limit of normal for AST
APRI alone may not be sufficiently sensitive to rule out significant disease
Combination with other indices (e.g., FIB-4) may improve diagnostic accuracy
Lower scores (<0.5) have high negative predictive value for ruling out cirrhosis
Higher scores (>1.5) have high positive predictive value for ruling in cirrhosis
Mid-range values (0.5-1.5) are less definitive and may require additional testing
